Headline.Para: Me & My Property; Buy, build and sell - that's her business strategy

LeadPara.Para: Ashleigh Ivory founder is working towards a fully paid-up penthouse and buying a few properties abroad
The founder and managing director of Ashleigh Ivory, Ms Cassiopea Yap, is constantly searching for quality products and services that promote a healthy family lifestyle.

TailParas.Para: Set up in 2007 with a paid-up capital of $500,000, her company - which has a staff strength of four to six - conceptualises and markets these products globally.
She broke even within two years before starting to turn "a good percentage of profit".
By the end of this year, the 52-year-old hopes to achieve a company revenue of $1 million.
Her firm has also launched its own brand of beauty products.
Ashleigh Ivory used to build business for other brands, but on a couple of occasions, the brand became so well known that the owners decided to terminate the partnership and go it alone.
"I decided to create my own brand and story, and I am learning to 'buy, build and sell' the business in the near future when I retire," Ms Yap said.
Ashleigh Ivory's first proprietary product - the Black Diamond Beauty Roller set - was launched last December. It consists of a lightweight facial roller and "Fuji Shiitake age-defying serum".

"This duo works to smooth furrow lines, reduce crow's feet and diminish sagging and baggy skin," said Ms Yap. "This pairing combats skin damage and fortifies the skin's cells to maximise their ability to protect, heal and restore."
She is married to senior financial consultant Eric Tan, 52, and they have a daughter Denyse, 25.
In 2010, the family sold their semi-detached house in the east of Singapore and rented a house in Seletar. They had to ballot for the house and it comes with a two-year renewable rental contract.
Q How would you describe your residential property?
A We lived in our double-storey semi-detached house at Upper East Coast for 15 years before cashing out in 2010 for a good profit.

In 2010, we moved to a three-plus-one-bedroom, 6,600 sq ft black and white semi-detached house at the former Seletar Airbase. The houses here were built to house officers from the British Royal Air Force before the outbreak of World War II.
Q What do you like about it?
A It's a peaceful area with plenty of tropical green spaces interspersed with black and white buildings, harking back to British colonial times.

This place is quiet with the surrounding trees and birds chirping in the morning. I have even seen the area covered in early morning mist, and I recently encountered a huge wild boar staring at me near my doorstep.
My favourite part of the property is my garden, where I can enjoy a cup of English tea with my English tea set as well as entertain guests with wine complete with lighted candles in the evening.
I have converted a garage into a storage room for my business.
Q What properties have you owned previously?
A I bought an apartment in Britain which was rented to students in 2011. It was sold in 2016.
In 1995, I shared the cost of buying a condo in the east of Singapore with friends and we sold it about a year later for a small profit.

I also bought a condo in the north of Singapore during the Gulf War in 1992 for $550,000. Back then, many people thought I was crazy to do that when I could easily have bought a landed property. I sold it after living there for two years and doubled my money.
Q How would you describe your property investment strategy?
A I usually leave sums to the experts, like my wealth consultant.
The factors I look out for when buying property are the potential capital appreciation, rental yield, location and condition of the property.
I do not have any mortgage now and we are waiting for the right time to re-invest in the property market.
We are working towards a fully-paid-up penthouse for my retirement and buying one or two additional investment properties overseas.
Q What do you think of the property market now?
A It's a good time for those looking for a unit. It is the right time to start investing.
Q What's your financing strategy?

A Buying a home is one of the biggest financial decisions I have had to make. It is always best to take time to check out the types of home loans available because, most of the time, the loans have a huge impact on my wallet.
Always ask about and understand the different components such as interest rate and refinancing fees.
As a businessperson, I take advantage of refinancing to improve my credit profile. A change in my long-term financial plans can also lead me to seek new credit terms and facilities.
A goal is to pay less interest over the life of my loan. There are times I may also want to change the duration of my loan or switch from a fixed-rate to adjustable-rate mortgage, or vice versa.
Q Do you have insurance cover for property and contents?
A Yes, insurance coverage is a must-have. Speak to your insurance agent for advice.
Q What's your overall investing strategy?
A My current approach and long-term goal is to invest for retirement over the next 10 years, as the cost of living is getting higher.

I want to find quality investment vehicles such as blue chip stocks and equity funds to buy and hold with the majority of my investment capital. My assets include equity, savings and business investments.
My retirement portfolio will preferably be a mixture of money market instruments. This mix also changes as I move towards low-risk guaranteed investments as I age.
Q What would be your dream home?
A We owned a semi-detached house in the east previously and I miss that location, as it is very convenient for driving to the seaside. It also has many amenities.
My next dream house would ideally be located in quiet surroundings with greenery.
I like swimming so a deep-lap pool would be ideal, as would a good size built-in wardrobe in my bedroom.
I've learnt to be in the moment, and enjoy the moments these days wherever I stay or travel.
